ry is required to determine its worst case release scenario for
listed toxic or flammable substances which may affect the community. Any
alternate or more likely release scenario must also be included. The hazard
assessment must include an estimate of potential release quantities
including the distance affected, and potential effects on people and the
environment. A five year accidental release is also included in the
assessments. Niacet has had no releases of RMP regulated chemicals in the
past 5 years.

Toxic Substances: Chlorine

The worst case release scenario for chlorine at Niacet Corporation is the
release of the contents of a full liquid railcar over a 10 minute period as
mandated by RMP guidelines. This scenario assumes that the entire 180,000
lbs of liquid chlorine vaporizes within the 10 minute interval. The worst
case scenario was evaluated using the EPA look up tables identified in the
Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance document. Under least favorable
weather conditions, the chlorine gas would travel a distance greater than
25 miles before the concentration was reduced to below 3 parts per million.
It is estimated that 1,200,000 people live within this 25 mile radius.

The alternative case scenario for chlorine is a failure of a 1 pipe at our
chlorine vaporizer. We estimate that this failure could result in the
release of 600 lbs of chlorine over a 20 minute interval. This scenario was
also evaluated using the EPA look up tables identified in the Offsite
Consequence Analysis Guidance document. It is estimated that this release
would travel a distance of 0.56 miles before the concentration was reduced
to below 3 parts per million. It is estimated that 600 people live within
this 0.56 mile radius.

Flammable Substances: Ethyl Ether

The worst case scenario for flammables is fixed by RMP guidelines. For this
scenario the entire contents of an ethyl ether tank at 83,000 lbs is
presumed to vaporize and produce a vapor cl

oud explosion which is a cloud
containing the flammable vapor and air. The end point for this scenario is
fixed at 1 psi overpressure. This scenario was evaluated using the EPA look
up tables identified in the Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance document.
It is estimated that this vapor cloud explosion would produce a 1 psi
overpressure up to 0.3 miles from our tank. There are no residences in this
radius.

The alternative case for flammables is the failure of an ethyl ether
transfer line in our tank farm. It is estimated that this failure could
result in the release of 8,300 lbs of ethyl ether into our tank farm dike
and then catching on fire. This scenario was also evaluated using the EPA
look up tables identified in the Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance
document. It is estimated that the radiant heat from the fire would
transfer a distance of 0.06  miles before the endpoint of 5kw/m2 for 40
seconds was reached. There are no residences in this area. Mitigation of
this scenario includes heat sensors that would trip a water deluge system
in our tank farm containment area.

Executive Summary

Niacet Corporation (Niacet) beagn as a semi-commercial chemical plant based on acetylene in 1924. The company is a privately owned corporation with approximately 80 full time employees. The facility operates
24 hours a day 365 days/year. The facility occupies 19 acres in a commercial/industrial area. The Niacet facility along with several other surrounding companies were all once owned by Union Carbide corporation. The facility is bordered by Niagara Falls Boulevard to the north,47th street to the west, and Simmons avenue to the south. The facility is bordered by a Praxair facility to the east. The nearest residential area is approximately 0.5 mi. To the NW. 

Niacet Corporation is a major producer of metal organic acid salts such as calcium propionate, sodium acetate, and sodium phenoxyacetate which is used in the fermentation of penicillin. Niacet produces monochloroacetic acid which is used in the manufacture of sodium phenoxyacetate,and also sold on the merchant market. Chlorine is used as a raw material in the production of monochloroacetic acid. Niacet uses ethyl ether in the manufacture of sodium phenoxyacetate and anionic surfactants.

Chlorine is received via railcar and transferred through a vaporizer into one of two 5,000 gal. chlorinators for the production of monochloroacetic acid. Niacet can have two 90 ton chlorine railcars on site for a total of 360,000 lbs. Safety systems include chlorine sensors, and automatic shut off valves.
Ethyl ether is received via tank truck. The ethyl ether is stored in two 14.000 gal. storage tanks. In total the two storage tanks can hold up to approximately 170,000 lbs. The ether is used in the manufacture of anionic surfactants, and also in the sodium phenoxyacetate process. The ether is recycled on site and reused in the processes. Safety systems include heat sensors that activate tank deluge systems, and ambient air LEL monitors. 
Niacet has developed a management system to oversee the implementation

of the RMP program elements. 
The Manager, Quality Assurance & Regulatory Affairs has the overall responsibility for the development, implementation,and integration of the RMP program elements.                                                                        The Manager,Quality Assurance& Regulatory Affairs reports directly to the co-Managing Directors. He may assign responsibility of individual requirements to qualified individuals identified in the Niacet organizational chart.
Niacet is committed to operating our Niagara Falls, NY facility in a safe and responsible manner. Our long history of no off site releases of RMP regulated chemicals speaks for itself. This is due to the layers of safeguards in place to prevent the release of hazardous substances. In the unlikely event of a chemical release, comprehensive emergency response plans are in place to bring any situation to a safe resolution. Niacet regularly meets with local emergency responders, and conducts on going training of emplyees and off site responders to be prepared in the unlikely event of an emergency situation.

Accident prevention is a key element of Niacet's RMP plan. We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releae of hazardous chemicals. Niacet's RMP plan includes the adoption of OSHA's accidental prevention program. Some key elements include: Operating procedures, Process safety information, Process hazard analysis, Training, Mechanical integrity, Incident investigations, Compliance audits, Management of change, Contractors, Pre-startup review, and Employee participation.

Planned changes to improve safety include our comprehensive safety improvement program. This includes the establishment of a joint Union/management Safety committee, review of our plant procedures, near misses and incident investigation programs, solicitation of suggestions, and the maintenance of regular departmental safety meetings.


 NIACET CORPORATION               12/31/03
